docs.title: Tesco High Level Design Documentation
docs.text: Welcome to the Tesco High Level Design (HLD) documentation site. This repository collects and organizes all HLDs across Tesco platforms, providing a single source of reference for architecture and design decisions.

docs.title: 📖 Contents
docs.text:
• Management Design – High-level design for management components.
  • Storage HLD – Storage architecture and standards.
  • TKS (Tesco Kubernetes Service) – Cluster design, networking, observability, RBAC, service naming, and UAT.
  • TPC (Tesco Platform Components) – Naming standards.
  • VMaaS (Virtual Machine as a Service) – HLD and network design.

docs.title: 🚀 How to Use
docs.text:
• Start with the Management and Storage sections for platform-wide foundations.
  • Review the TKS and VMaaS sections for workload platform designs.
  • Refer to TPC for consistent naming and standards.

docs.title: 1. Overview
docs.text:
• Objective: Provide Virtual Machine as a Service on OpenShift Virtualization (KubeVirt).
  • Business Value: Enable Tesco teams to run VM workloads alongside containers.
  • Scope: VM provisioning, lifecycle management, storage, networking, RBAC, observability.
  • Non-Goals: Application-specific functional testing.

docs.title: 2. Architecture
docs.text:
• Platform: OpenShift Virtualization (KubeVirt).
  • Core components: virt-api, virt-controller, virt-handler, CDI, HCO.
  • VM templates: base OS images (RHEL, Windows, Ubuntu).
  • Storage integration: .
  • Networking: Multus-based secondary interfaces, VLAN trunking.
  • Namespaces: One namespace per business group.

docs.title: 3. Provisioning & Lifecycle
docs.text:
• VM creation from templates.
  • Snapshots and cloning support.
  • Live migration policies.
  • Backup & restore integration.
  • Scaling strategy (per BG, quota limits).

docs.title: 4. Security
docs.text:
• Isolation: Namespaces + MultiNetworkPolicy.
  • RBAC: Tenant-admin, tenant-developer roles.
  • Image provenance: signed golden images, scanning for vulnerabilities.
  • Secrets: mounted via Kubernetes Secrets, sealed-secrets for GitOps.

docs.title: 5. Operations
docs.text:
• Monitoring: VM metrics (CPU, memory, disk I/O).
  • Logging: VM console logs → cluster logging stack.
  • Alerting: integrated with Prometheus/Grafana.
  • Day-2 Ops: patching golden images, policy enforcement.

docs.title: 6. Backup & Disaster Recovery
docs.text:
• RPO/RTO targets:
  • Tooling: Velero, OADP, or vendor-specific backup.
  • Replication: across regions / AZs.

docs.title: 7. Risks & Decisions
docs.text:
• Storage backend performance variability.
  • VLAN overlap between tenants.
  • Pending decision: standard template catalog.

docs.title: 1. Overview
docs.text:
• Objective: Define the network design for Virtual Machine as a Service (VMaaS) running on OpenShift Virtualization.
  • Scope: VM connectivity, VLAN trunking, MultiNetworkPolicy, ingress/egress, performance and HA.
  • Non-Goals: Application-level network configuration.

docs.title: 2. Network Topology
docs.text:
• Primary pod network: used for cluster services (OVN-Kubernetes).
  • Secondary networks: provided via Multus, connected using VLAN trunking.
  • VLAN allocation: each Business Group (BG) maps to one or more VLANs.
  • IPAM strategy: static/dynamic pools managed per namespace.

docs.title: 3. Multi-Network Support
docs.text:
• Multus CNI: attach multiple interfaces per VM.
  • NAD (NetworkAttachmentDefinition): defines VLAN-backed networks.
  • Use cases:
  • Isolated tenant networks.
  • Shared services networks (backup, monitoring).
  • Constraints: multiple BGs may share a VLAN/subnet.

docs.title: 4. Network Security Policies
docs.text:
• Baseline rules: applied across all namespaces.
  • Tenant rules: BGs define their own MultiNetworkPolicies.
  • Enforcement: IP-based (no NSX-style tags).
  • Segmentation strategy: namespace isolation + VLAN separation.

docs.title: 5. Ingress & Egress
docs.text:
• Ingress: via OpenShift routes, LoadBalancer services, or dedicated Ingress VMs.
  • Egress: NAT gateways or egress firewall policies.
  • North-south control: firewall rules enforced at cluster edge.
  • DNS: centralized service per cluster.

docs.title: 6. High Availability & Performance
docs.text:
• Redundant physical NICs: bonded for failover.
  • Trunk uplinks: multiple uplinks per node for resiliency.
  • MTU considerations: jumbo frames for storage/backup networks.
  • QoS: priority handling for critical services.

docs.title: 7. Testing & Validation
docs.text:
• Connectivity matrix: verify inter-VM and inter-namespace reachability.
  • Performance tests: measure bandwidth, latency, jitter.
  • Failure simulations: node NIC down, switch failure.
  • Conformance tests: validate NADs and MultiNetworkPolicies.

docs.title: 8. Risks & Open Items
docs.text:
• VLAN/subnet overlap between BGs.
  • Limited policy granularity (IP-only enforcement).
  • Pending decision: centralized vs. decentralized IPAM.

docs.title: 1. Principles
docs.text:
• Least Privilege: Grant only the permissions required for a role.
  • Separation of Duties: Separate operational vs. development access.
  • Namespace Isolation: Tenants restricted to their namespaces.
  • Auditability: All role changes must be traceable through GitOps/PRs.

docs.title: 2. Role Model
docs.text:
• Platform Roles
  • platform-admin → full control across all namespaces.
  • platform-readonly → read-only across cluster.
  • Tenant Roles
  • tenant-admin → admin rights within their own namespaces.
  • tenant-developer → limited create/update/delete in dev/test namespaces.
  • tenant-reader → read-only within tenant namespaces.

docs.title: 3. Role Bindings
docs.text:
• Identity provider integration: map AD/SSO groups → Kubernetes roles.
  • ServiceAccounts: used for automation, CI/CD pipelines.
  • Binding strategy: GitOps-managed RBAC definitions (ArgoCD/ACM).

docs.title: 4. Permission Matrix
docs.text: Role Namespace Scope Permissions platform-admin * * (all verbs, all resources) platform-readonly * get, list, watch tenant-admin tenant--* admin within tenant namespaces tenant-developer tenant--dev/test CRUD on workloads, read infra resources tenant-reader tenant--* get, list, watch

docs.title: 5. Patterns & Best Practices
docs.text:
• Impersonation accounts: restricted use for troubleshooting.
  • Break-glass roles: temporary elevated access with audit logging.
  • Namespace labels: used to auto-bind tenant roles.
  • Drift detection: RBAC must match Git state.

docs.title: 6. Compliance & Audit
docs.text:
• RBAC definitions reviewed quarterly.
  • All role requests go through Pull Request workflow.
  • Automated drift detection alerts.
  • Audit logs sent to Tesco SIEM.

docs.title: 7. Risks & Open Items
docs.text:
• Risk of privilege escalation if namespace boundaries are misconfigured.
  • Pending decision: standard naming convention for AD/SSO groups.

docs.text:

docs.title: 1. Purpose
docs.text: Consistent service naming ensures: - Predictability for developers and operators. - Alignment with Tesco’s enterprise naming conventions. - Compatibility with DNS, certificates, and monitoring systems.

docs.title: 2. Naming Convention
docs.text:
General format:

  • org → tesco
  • team → business unit or product team name (short form)
  • service → logical service name
  • env → dev, test, stage, prod
  • region → region or site code (uks, uke, gcp-eu, etc.)

docs.title: Rules
docs.text:
• Lowercase alphanumeric and - only.
  • Maximum length: 63 characters (Kubernetes DNS label limit).
  • Must start with a letter.
  • No trailing hyphens.

docs.title: 3. Examples
docs.text:
• tesco-payments-api-prod-uks
  • tesco-catalog-worker-dev-uke
  • tesco-search-ui-stage-gcp-eu

docs.title: 4. Reserved Words
docs.text: The following words may not be used as team or service values: - core - shared - platform - infra

docs.title: 5. Validation (Regex)
docs.text: This regex enforces lowercase words separated by hyphens, 3–6 segments.

docs.title: 6. DNS & Certificates
docs.text:
• Service names must be valid Kubernetes DNS subdomains.
  • Wildcard and SAN certificates should match naming conventions.
  • Certificate rotation must align with service naming scheme.

docs.title: 7. Ownership & Review
docs.text:
• Naming requests reviewed by platform team.
  • Automated validation runs in CI/CD pipelines.
  • Violations block deployments until corrected.

docs.title: 8. Risks & Open Items
docs.text:
• Teams may attempt to shorten names excessively → ambiguity risk.
  • Pending decision: whether to enforce standard across all namespaces.

docs.title: 9. References
docs.text:
• Kubernetes DNS Label Names
  • Tesco internal naming ADRs

docs.title: 1. Purpose
docs.text: Consistent naming of Tesco Platform Components (TPC) ensures: - Predictability for developers, operators, and auditors. - Alignment with Tesco enterprise-wide naming rules. - Compatibility with Kubernetes, DNS, and cloud provider constraints.

docs.title: 2. Scope
docs.text: This document applies to: - Git repositories - Container images - Clusters and namespaces - Storage buckets - Messaging topics/queues - Any platform-level shared resources

docs.title: 3. General Rules
docs.text:
• Lowercase alphanumeric and hyphens (-) only.
  • Maximum length: 63 characters (Kubernetes DNS label limit).
  • Must start with a letter and end with alphanumeric.
  • Hyphen-separated segments preferred (team-service-env).

docs.text: Do not use the following as standalone names: - core - shared - infra - platform

docs.text:
• Legacy resources renamed during scheduled maintenance.
  • Redirects/aliases applied where possible.
  • Documented change logs.

docs.title: 8. Risks & Open Items
docs.text:
• Long names may exceed character limits in some cloud providers.
  • Pending decision: standard abbreviations for regions (uks, uke, etc.).
